Many have prior critical care or medical-surgical nursing experience. 91 Nonetheless, some, especially those resuming employment after a leave of absence, may choose 92 to supplement their previous education and experience and thus be better prepared to work 93 outside perioperative settings. TABREF1.text: Aligning with national recommendations, 25 the DOD directed military treatment facilities to 138 postpone all non-essential surgeries and procedures, thereby enhancing the safety of medical 139 personnel, prolonging supplies of PPE, and ensuring the availability of military medical 140 personnel to provide care where needed. 26 Surgeons continued to perform emergency surgical 141 procedures and operations that military members needed in order to be deployment ready. Thus, 142 some perioperative and perianesthesia nurses continued their usual work. 143 Medical center leadership directed changes to the physical layout of the OR and the PACU. A 144 section of OR suites, with sterile core access, was converted to negative pressure. Temporary 145 wall barriers were erected in the PACU to facilitate surgical cohorting by COVID-19 status. 146 Perioperative and perianesthesia nurse administrators focused on the flow of COVID-19 and Senior hospital executives consulted with perioperative and perianesthesia nurses to develop a 152 Concept of Operations Plan that included a surge plan and interdisciplinary staffing model. The most powerful lesson learned is that perioperative and perianesthesia nurses have the 205 requisite knowledge and skills to provide expert clinical care in many hospital settings and meet 206 the demands of a global pandemic. Perioperative and perianesthesia nurses were affable to duty 207 assignment changes, which sometimes required additional training, enabling them to work in 208 different or higher levels of care. Nursing is a calling, 32 and it was refreshing to see perioperative 209 and perianesthesia nurses rise to new challenges, adapt to changes outside of their norm, and 210 meet the needs of the greater good. Although specialty trained to provide care to surgical 211 patients, organizations should view perioperative and perianesthesia nurses as potent enablers to 212 the overall nursing viability of the health system. Furthermore, we learned that for operational 213 success, the hospital and nursing response must be flexible to policy changes, scientific 214 advances, and increased demand. Hospital leadership instituted rapid changes across the medical 215 center, based on the latest evidence, which potentially saved lives and reduced transmission of 216 COVID-19. Lastly, clear lines of communication between leadership and staff are essential to 217 promote shared understanding, 33 increase engagement, and reduce clinician stress. In this manuscript, we 224 described the changing roles and contributions of perioperative and perianesthesia registered 225 nurses during the COVID-19 pandemic and shared recent experiences from a military medical 226 center.
